rationale1: The claim cites a 'viral message' to support a scary health warning.
rationale2: The headline uses Availability Bias via a 'viral message'. It uses Illusory Correlation to link 'leftover rice' to cancer.

text: Smart watches are actually tracking devices for the government.
rationale1: The headline reframes a consumer gadget as a government tracking tool.
rationale2: The text uses Availability Bias by reframing smart watches as 'tracking devices'. It validates fears of government spying.

text: Grandmother's secret: Applying onion juice regrows hair in 10 days.
rationale1: The text promises a quick miracle cure based on folk wisdom.
rationale2: The claim relies on Naturalness Bias/Folk wisdom ('Grandmother'). It promises 'onion juice' regrows hair in 10 days.

text: Urgent: Delete this photo editing app, it is stealing your photos.
rationale1: The claim demands immediate action ('Delete') to protect personal photos.
rationale2: The headline uses Availability Bias with 'Urgent'. It demands app deletion to prevent photo theft.

text: Doctors say that drinking tea in plastic cups causes cancer.
rationale1: The headline uses medical authority to link a common habit to cancer.
rationale2: The text uses Availability Bias via 'Doctors say'. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias (plastic is toxic) and Illusory Correlation by linking 'tea in plastic cups' directly to cancer.
